loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a member of the Kinanambo borrower group in Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 40 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 5 children.Her children are aged 22,20,18,15,12 years.

Judith started her own Tailoring business 3 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Judith`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more material for her business.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Judith hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Belgica Maritza

texts.es:
La señora Bélgica es socia del Banco Comunal Nueva Generación, un grupo relativamente nuevo que se reúne cada dos semanas en el Barrio Cuba en la ciudad de Manta, Provincia de Manabí, en la costa ecuatoriana.

Bélgica tiene 26 años y vive en unión libre con su pareja y su hijo de 2.5 años. Ella se dedica a la venta de sábanas, cortinas, y medicina natural. Su mamá le trae las cortinas y sábanas desde la ciudad de Guayaquil, y la medicina natural es de un catálogo. 

Vende de casa en casa, y también viaja fuera de la ciudad de Manta para vender sus productos. Sus clientas son generalmente sus amigas y antiguas compañeras de trabajo. Se dedica a esta actividad desde los 22 años y,  dice que aunque las ventas siempre suben y bajan le va bastante bien, y vende $30-$40 de mercadería cada semana. Le gusta su trabajo. 

Actualmente está pidiendo un crédito para comprar sábanas y cortinas con nuevos diseños y colores de moda e incrementar su stock de medicina natural.  No invertirá todo el crédito en la compra, sino que lo invertirá poco a poco de acuerdo a sus necesidades.

 Su meta para el futuro es poner una tienda en su casa, con vitrinas y todo. Lleva 2 ciclos trabajando con su banco comunal, y dice que es “una gran oportunidad que le brindan” porque los intereses son bajos y los pagos quincenales le convienen.
texts.en:
Bélgica is a member of the “Nueva Generación” communal bank, a relatively new group that meets every two weeks in the Cuba neighborhood in the city of Manta, in the province of Manabí, on the coast of Ecuador. Bélgica is 26 years old and lives with her common-law husband and her 2.5 year-old son. She sells sheets, curtains, and natural medicine. Her mother brings her the curtains and sheets from the city of Guayaquil, and the natural medicine is from a catalog. She sells door-to-door and she also travels outside the city of Manta to sell her products. Her customers are usually her friends and her acquaintances from her old job. She has been working in this business since she was 22 years old. She says that though sales always rise and fall, things are going very well and she sells $30 to $40 of merchandise per week. She likes her work. She is requesting a loan in order to buy sheets and curtains with new designs and fashionable colors and to increase her stock of natural medicines. She won’t invest all of her loan at once in purchases; rather she will spend it bit by bit as needed. Her goal for the future is to open a store in her house, with vitrines and all. She has been with the communal bank for two loan cycles, and she says it’s “a great opportunity being provided” because the interest is low and the twice-monthly payments work well for her.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheets and curtains in fashionable colors and designs and to increase her stock of natural medicine products

loans.name: Luis Manuel

texts.es: Luis Manuel es soltero,  vive en la zona # 4 en Nueva Guinea, trabaja como cajero del PALI de esta ciudad desde hace 2 años, esta solicitando su primer  crédito a AFODENIC para inventirlo  en la construccion de un cuarto en la casa de su mamá que es donde habita, y de esta manera poder tener mayor comodidad y privacidad, en su comunidad es conocido como un joven responsable, trabajador  que a pesar que no tiene hijos ayuda a su mamà con los gastos familiares,en su centro de trabajo y su barrio es  muy querido  por ser una persona de buen vivir y muy alegre, su sueño es seguir estudiando y que su familia siempre permanezca unida.
texts.en:
Luis Manuel is unmarried and lives in Zone 4 in Nueva Guinea (New Guinea), Nicaragua. He has been working as a cashier in his town’s PALI (supermarket chain) for 2 years. He is asking for his first loan from AFODENIC to invest in the construction of a room in his mother’s house where he lives so that he can be more comfortable and have greater privacy. He is known as a responsible young man in his community. Despite not having any children, he works to help his mother with the household expenses. Both in his place of work and his neighbourhood he is treasured as a lively and happy person. His dream is to continue his studies and that his family will always stay together.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a room in his mother's house

loans.name: One Business Group

texts.en:
One Business is group of four borrowers led by Patricia S.. She is a 28-year-old high school graduate and a single mother of a 6-year-old child who attends kindergarten. She lives in Waterside, a commercial area of downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Patricia's business is clothing.She buys clothes wholesale and sells at retail to the residents of downtown Monrovia, Liberia.
She started this business with LD $5000.00 and has been running her business for eight years. She hopes to expand her business to a bigger store.
Patricia sells quality products and gives her customers a better approach to encourage them to always come to patronize her business.
She needs a loan in order to purchase more quality goods to expand her business.
Patricia dreams of giving her children a better education and good health care.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy D. is from the village of Sabacan Panadtalan, Maramag Bukidnon. She is 44 years old. Daisy is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Daisy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Daisy has been in business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Daisy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP ,which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Daisy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Akello Margaret Group

texts.en:
A. Margaret is 39 years old and blessed with four children, all of whom are in school. She also looks after three dependents, who are also schooling.

Margaret deals in produce such as beans and groundnuts. She is requesting a loan to purchase more produce in order to increase her stock. She wishes to purchase six bags of each produce (beans, groundnuts, etc.). Margaret is an active businesswoman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more produce (beans, groundnuts, etc.) in order to increase her stock

loans.name: Philo

texts.en: Philo is 28 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist. She is a hair stylist and she also sells hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. She is happy because the high season is here and her sales will increase. Philo lives in Edo State, Nigeria and is hoping for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions to sell to her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia T. is from the village of Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 57 years old. Emilia is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Emilia owns and operates a business venture in the services sector, operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transportation services to local community members. Emilia has been engaged in her motorcycle business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Wilberforce Osonyo

texts.en: Wilberforce Osonyo M. is a 37-year-old man, married and blessed with 3 children. He runs his own farm from which he supplies crops to the local market at Malanga, Busia district. Wilberforce started farming at around 15 years of age. He admits he was never good at books but in farming he is an A student. He would like a loan of Kshs. 30,000 to buy seedliings, fertilizer and hire labour for the new farm extension he made in preparation for the next rains.

loans.use: Buy seedlings, fertilizer, and hire labour

loans.name: Hin

texts.en:
This photo presents Mrs. Hin S., a woman who subsists on a low-income. She lives in Kampong Chhnang province. Hin is a widowed mother who is blessed with one daughter. The daughter has completed secondary school and presently works in the garment industry. Hin farms a rice crop to earn a living.

Recently Hin decided that she could earn more money from investing in a new enterprise. She has asked for a loan to use as capital to order mature rice from other farmers, which she will then sell to raise revenue.

loans.use: To order mature rice to sell.

loans.name: Dewompele #3 Group

texts.en: Kumba P. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Dewompele #3. She is 38 years old and is married with four children aged 10 to 24 years with educational level of 5th grade through university freshman student. She also cares for a grandchild. Kumba and her family lives in West Point, a very crowded and poor community close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She could not continue her education after 8th grade due to her developing eye problem. Kumba’s business is the sale of cosmetics for children. She buys her stock from wholesalers and sells retail in the Waterside market in downtown Monrovia. She has been running this business for six years and is hoping to own a cosmetics store in the near future. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Kumba started by selling underwear and her capital was 700 Liberian dollars. She then raised money to get into children’s cosmetics sales. She needs this loan to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She dreams of giving her children a better education and helping them to establish themselves. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kumba P. is the one holding the sign. Siah A. is inset at lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: George Group

texts.en:
James K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called George Group. He is 58 years old, married, and has three children who are 14, 24, and 26 years old.

For over 30 years James has had a tailoring business at the Happy Corner Market. His parents gave him his first machine. James says that he always tries to satisfy his customers and his clothes are good quality, which helps his business.

James plans to use his portion of the group loan to buy more clothes to sell. His goal is to have a big personal tailor shop and to help his children in every way possible.

In the photo James is holding the sign. Alice B. is in the inset at lower right.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: María Irene

texts.es: María Irene C. D. P. D. 52 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. La Paz. Vive junto a su esposo y dos nietos D. 17 y 15 años D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar gracias al extraordinario trabajo y esfuerzo D. sus abuelos. La señora María se dedica a la compra D. cerdos D. granja, los cuales alimenta y cría para posteriormente vender o destazar para vender la carne. Así mismo se encarga D. procesar leche D. vaca la cual posteriormente sale a vender por las calles del departamento D. La Paz. DesD. hace 5 años que María tuvo la iniciativa D. emprender su propio negocio el cual le permitiera obtener ganancias extras y poder mejorar la estabilidad económica D. su familia. Es por esta razón que decidió utilizar el espacio con el que cuenta en el patio D. su casa y poner una pequeña granja D. cerdos. María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. comida para cerdo, así mismo comprar más cerdos, los cuales pueda criar D. la mejor manera para luego vender a sus clientes. María posee una gran necesidad D. las ganancias D. este negocio, es por ello que cuenta con el deseo D. poder mejorarlo y seguir adelante con este.
texts.en:
María Irene C. D. P., 52, lives in La Paz department with her husband and two grandsons, who are 17 and 15 years of age; they can focus on being students thanks to the extraordinary efforts of their grandparents. María raises domestic pigs that she later either sells or butchers to sell the meat. She also processes cow's milk that she peddles along La Paz department's streets. It was five years ago that María took the initiative to start her own business that would make it possible for her to have extra income and be able to improve her family's economic stability. For this reason, she decided to use the space available in her yard to set up a small pig farm. María is asking for funding to buy more pig feed as well as more pigs to raise for subsequent sale to her customers. María's need for the profits from these sales is great, thus her desire to improve them and get ahead in life through them.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs and pig feed.

loans.name: Maria Felipa

texts.es:
La señora MARIA FELIPA D. J. tiene 56 años, vive en la provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal LA PERBOLA II. La socia  presenta estudios superiores hasta 6to de Primaria refiere que sus padres no le facilitaron mas educación porque no tenían recursos económicos, está casada, tiene 6 hijos de los cuales 1 depende económicamente de ella. La socia  se dedica a la confección  de peluches y mochilas para niños. Para la confección de los peluches y mochilas ella utiliza insumos como: peluche, tela polar, algodón industrial hilos, blondas, etc. y compra estos productos al por mayor en  el mercado mayorista porque los obtiene a menor costo lo cual le favorece, sus productos los vende en forma ambulatoria.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró material como: tela de peluche, algodón, felpa, cierre, hilos, agujas, lana, etc. 
Con este crédito de  1,000.00 comprará mas material como: telas de algodón , telas de felpa , telas de polar, relleno de algodón , cierre, etc. para que haga mochilas para los niños de Inicial y de Primaria.
Ella sueña con aumentar sus ventas, sus ganancias y poder alquilar un puesto en un mercado o centro comercial en donde exhibir sus mochilas y muñecos para así poder generar mayores ventas e ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
María Felipa D. J. is 56, and she lives in the Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She belongs to the La Perbola II Communal Bank. She went to school until the sixth grade. Her parents did not have the economic resources to give her more education. She has six children, and one is economically dependent upon her. She makes stuffed animals and backpacks for children. To make the stuffed animals and backpacks she uses supplies like felt, polar fleece, industrial cotton thread, and silk lace, etc. She buys these products in the wholesale market because she gets them at a favorable lower cost. She sells her products as a traveling vendor. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought material like fabric for stuffed animals, cotton, felt, zippers, thread, pins, and wool, etc. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy more material like cotton fabric, felt, polar fleece, cotton filling, and zippers to make backpacks for children in primary and secondary school. She dreams of increasing her sales and her earnings and being able to rent a stand in the market or the commercial center where they display backpacks and stuffed animals. That way she would be able to generate greater sales and income for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material like fabric for stuffed animals, cotton, felt, zippers, thread, pins, and wool, etc.

loans.name: Kantossowe

texts.en: Kantossowe D. is 59 years old, has one child, and is a widow. She lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo, and works from home. She makes and sells a local beverage called tchoukoutou (a local beer) and has been in this business since 1975. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to purchase necessary items to make this beverage – namely, a grain called sorgho and firewood. These items will allow Mrs. D. to augment her supply of tchoukoutou and keep her customers satisfied.

loans.use: Purchase of incredients to prepare and sell local beverage

loans.name: Rosita Yasely

texts.es:
Rosita tiene 24 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a sus padres en el caserío Insculas, una zona rural del distrito de Olmos, ubicado en la provincia de Lambayeque, a dos horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace un año a la venta de prendas de vestir, ella adquiere su mercadería con frecuencia en la ciudad de Chiclayo y la comercializa entre sus vecinos, este negocio tiene acogida en la zona ya que queda alejada de la ciudad de Chiclayo y no tienen acceso a prendas de vestir baratas. Rosita nos comenta que inició el negocio llevada por la necesidad de obtener una fuente permanente de ingresos que le permita solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar a la economía de su familia.

El negocio goza de buena acogida entre los vecinos de la zona y ella piensa ampliarlo, por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de más ropa para ofrecérsela a sus clientes.

Rosita es una joven trabajadora y responsable, su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria para poder percibir mas ingresos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida, sus vecinos y conocidos la consideran una mujer de confianza.
texts.en:
Rosita, 24, is single and lives with her parents in Insculas, a rural area of Olmos, Lambayeque province, which is two hours away from the city of Chiclayo. She has sold clothing for the last year; she buys her merchandise frequently in Chiclayo and sells to her neighbors. Her business has been well-received because the area is far from the city of Chiclayo and they don’t have easy access to low cost clothing. Rosita tells us that she started the business because she needed to have a permanent source of income in order to meet her personal expenses and contribute to her family’s support. Her business is well-received among her neighbors in the area and she plans to expand it. This has led her to approach Edpyme Alternativa for the first time to request a 1000 new sol loan to buy more stock merchandise. Rosita is a hard-working, responsible young woman; her greatest wish is to continue to grow as a businesswoman in order to earn higher income and provide her family with improved quality of life. Her neighbors and acquaintances consider her trustworthy.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy articles of clothing.

loans.name: Ñamba'apo Hagua(Para Trabajar) Group

texts.es:
El comité “Ñamba'apo hagua” (para trabajar) está conformada por 18 integrantes, en la ciudad de Mariano Roque Alonso. 
Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, empleada Doméstica.
 Las integrantes participan puntualmente en las reuniones semanales  y en la Capacitaciones, demostraron interés con respecto al Programa Comité de Mujeres y todos los programas de la Fundación Paraguaya.
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a varias actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable y con vistas a un crecimiento constante, con la ayuda de una asistencia financiera permanente.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Blanca quien se dedica a la venta de mercaderías varias, tales como enlatados, alimentos no perecederos, golosinas, bebidas, descartables, etc. distribuidos al detalle a los consumidores en general y tambien a pequeñas tiendas dedicadas al ramo.
Su intención principal es la ampliación del ramo de su negocio, procurando implementar otros medios de distribución como serían pequeños carritos, para facilitar la entrega de mercaderías a los clientes, todo teniendo en cuenta la demanda que posee gracias a la buena clientela ya formada.
texts.en:
The group “Ñamba'apo hagua” (“To Work”), comprised of 18 members, is in the city of Mariano Roque Alonso. All the members of this group carry out their own activities, which include working as merchants and maids. The members are punctual about attending their weekly meetings, and demonstrated interest in the Women’s Programs and all the programs of Fundación Paraguaya. All the members are mothers who carry out various activities in order to contribute to the financial stability of their households. They have hopes of growing their businesses in a sustainable manner, and want to see continued growth along with the assistance of permanent financial support. One of the members is Blanca, who dedicates herself to selling various types of products such as canned goods, non-perishables, snacks, beverages, etc. She distributes her merchandise both directly to the consumer, as well as to small stores that also sell these types of goods. Her primary goal is to expand her business and finding other means of distributing her merchandise by other means, such as small carts, so that she can sell to a greater number of customers. She makes all her plans based on the demand she has thanks to the good customer base she has established.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large quantities of beverages, canned goods, bread products, etc.

loans.name: Renel

texts.en:
Renel S. is from the village of Palutan. He is 40 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Renel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting corn for sale. Renel has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 55,000 PHP during harvest season.
In 2009, Renel joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Renel is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be his third from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita S. is from Gingoog City. She is 51 years old. Anita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Anita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Anita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married with two grown children. She is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye who sells bags, purses, wallets, backpacks, etc., in one of the local markets called “Krytyi” (“Covered”). She has been in this trade for twelve years. Currently, she has about 20,000 Grivnyas in inventory and her gross turnover amounts to 13,000 Grivnyas. She is seeking a 6,000 Grivnya loan to diversify her assorted merchandise.

Galina started her small vending business selling hair combs, small cosmetics gifts, and manicure sets. However, later, she decided to change the type of inventory she offers for sale and started selling purses and backpacks. She admits that she likes working with this merchandise because it sells well and is easily transported.

loans.use: To purchase summer merchandise for her business

loans.name: Jimena

texts.es:
La señora Jimena S. O. tiene 32 años es madre soltera con dos hijos Abigail y Lorena de 15 años y el pequeño Juan de 2 años. Viven en su casa propia  en la zona de barrio 30 de agosto en la zona sud del plan 3000 una de las zonas pobres de Santa Cruz de la Sierra. 

La señora trabaja en una empresa de transporte en el área de despacho de cargas es una de las personas mas responsable que trabaja en dicha empresa pero sus ingresos son muy  bajos. La señora Jimena requiere el dinero par poder ampliar su casa ya que es muy pequeña y así poder darle un mejor ambiente a sus hijos en el cual puedan vivir y así poder mejorar su calidad de vida
texts.en:
Jimena S. O. is a 32 year old single mother, with 2 fifteen year old daughters, Abigail and Lorena, and a little boy, Juan, who is 2. They live in their own house in the 30 de Agosto district, in the area south of Plan 3000 - one of the poorest areas in Santa Cruz de la Sierra. Jimena works for a dispatch company. She is a very responsible person and although she works, her income is very low. She needs the money to be able to extend her home, which is currently very small. That will mean she can give her children a better place to live and so improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a dwelling

loans.name: Clorinda

texts.es: Clorinda tiene 36 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en su casa propia. Desde que era niña, se dedico a las labores agrícolas, en la actualidad ésta es su principal fuente de ingreso, es por ello que su familia vela cada día por los terrenos ya cultivados, cuidándolas, aplicando abono y regándolas, procuran además que la plaga de insectos no perjudique las plantaciones y que afectan en la cosecha. Aunque las labores del campo sean arduas, afirma que le gusta mucho trabajar en esta actividad porque le permite tener siempre disponible el alimento para su familia. El cultivo de hortalizas es lo más rentable que tiene, pero también cultiva papa para aumentar sus ganancias, es por esta razón que desea intensificar sus cultivos, producir en mayor cantidad estos productos ya que ofrecen un buen precio por su venta en el mercado local de su zona. En adelante desea  adquirir más extensiones de terreno donde pueda seguir produciendo más. Este es su décimo crédito con MFP, esta muy contenta de  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su grupo comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, agradece aquellas personas que serán gestoras del préstamo que solicita, por que le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, invertirá en la compra de semillas y compost (tierra preparada) para agregar a sus terrenos y de esa manera mejorar la cosecha de papa y hortalizas.
texts.en:
Clorinda is 36 years old. She lives with her husband and 3 children in her own home. Since she was a child Clorinda has worked in agriculture, and this is her main source of earnings. Each day her family watches over the cultivated land, looking after the crops, applying fertiliser, watering them, trying to ensure that the plagues of insects don't damage the plants and affect the crop. Although agricultural work is hard, Clorinda affirms that she likes the work a lot because it allows her to be free to feed her family. Vegetable cultivation is the most profitable, producing a large quantity of products that get a good price in the local market in the zone. In the future Clorinda wants to acquire more land where she can continue to produce more. This is her tenth loan with MFP and she is very content to know that she has financial support. She has always been responsible with her repayments, and is thankful to be part of a communal bank as all the members are responsible and supportive people. Clorinda is thankful that the members will be guarantors for the loan she is seeking, as it will be very useful for her business. With the loan she is seeking Clorinda plans to invest in the purchase of seeds and compost (prepared earth) to add to her land and in this way improve her potato and vegetable crops.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds and compost

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Khim K. is a long-time businesswoman and a low-income person. She has been operating a beauty business since the beginning of this year. In the local market, she owns a kiosk where she sells different kinds of miscellaneous materials. She sells items such as perfumes, beauty products, and some fake jewelry to people who come to buy anything in the market. Khim K. is married to 30-year-old, Choun Chenda, who is a professional teacher. The couple is blessed with a young kid who is still not enrolled in school. In order to earn extra profit and to make the business more successful, Khim K. will be using the loan she requested to accumulate a larger quantity of her inventory items.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger quantity of inventory items

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Twenty-six-year-old Bernard Okang'a O. is married and has two children, three and two years old; he and his wife hope to give their children a good education to the university level. Operating a business selling such items as padlocks, torches, knives, belts, mirrors and sunglasses located in a very busy place at Kakamega, Bernard sells to walk-ins and repeat customers. In business for two years now, he says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has are financial constraints. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well.

He is using his loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more padlocks, umbrellas, knives, bolts, mirrors and sunglasses and hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as ambitious and patient.

loans.use: To purchase padlocks, torches, knives, belts, mirrors and sunglasses

loans.name: Tua

texts.en:
Tua A. is 45, married, and has one child. She owns a business venture selling baked goods in the local community. Tua has one year of experience in this business. She is requesting a loan of 1,000 WST to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 WST per week) to improve and expand her business.
Tua joined Kiva partner, SPBD, in 2010, and this is her first loan. SPBD's loans are Tua's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a housewife, while her husband operates his truck to transport workers from the garment factory, earning an income of $8 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to grow rice

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en: Epiphanie is 36 years old, and she has three children between the ages of 14 and 3. She is married to a builder. All of her children attend school. She sells potatoes, cassava and yams and this loan will be used to purchase larger quantities than what she has been selling in the past. With the profit she will pay school fees for her children. Her business is well known by her customers and most of them go to her to purchase their daily needs. She would like to own her own truck so that she can supply in large volume. She is proud of her business because it has done tremendous things towards her well-being.

loans.use: buy more potatoes, cassava and yams for resale

loans.name: Nerys Amarilis

texts.es: Nerys Amarilis tiene 26 años, se dedica a una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación. Por lo que no es la primera vez que solicita crédito, pues ha sido beneficios para su actividad.  Hace más de 4 años que inicio ella tiene la responsabilidad de sacar a su familia adelante, fue por iniciativa propia que logro obtener este medio de vida. Poco a poco es que ella ha mejorado su negocio y además obtiene clientes nuevos cada día. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan y jugos.
texts.en: Nerys Amarilis is twenty-six and earns her living running a grocery located in her house.  This isn't the first time she has requested a loan, and the loans have benefited her business. She started out more than four years ago.  She's responsible for getting her family ahead, and it was through her own initiative that she obtained this lifestyle.  Little by little she has improved the business and is getting new clientele by the day.  Nerys Amarilis is seeking this loan to purchase basic grains, candy, natural soft drinks, bread, and juices.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Jenefer Nana Ama Ampomah

texts.en:
Jenefer Nana Ama Ampomah D. is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. She has senior high educational background. Jenefer sells pastries at Asenadze near Abura. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She is asking for the loan to enable her to expand her business. Janefer hopes to reinvest her additional income.

In this photo, Jenefer is showing the flour and oil she uses for her pastries.

loans.use: expand her business

loans.name: Pedro Cesar

texts.es:
Pedro de 63 años, alquila parasoles para los turistas en la playa.  Vive en un cantón llamado Playas uno de los lugares turísticos del Ecuador con una diversa dimensión de mariscos.  

Hace 35 años su suegra murió y el comenzó administrar el negocio que ella tenía para que el trabajo familiar continúe.  Por la buena administración que ha hecho con el negocio lo conocen muy los turistas para alquilar parasoles. Trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta las 17h00 en la playa alquilando cada parasol a $ 5.00 incluido sillas, carpas a $ 5.00 según sea el tamaño. 

Para continuar con su negocio el quiere comprar con el préstamo parasoles, carpas, sillas para que sus clientes tengan más variedad. En el futuro quiere tener un local frente a la playa para darle un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Peter is 63 years old. He rents umbrellas to tourists on the beach. He lives in an area called “Beaches”, one of the tourist locations in Ecuador that has a large variety of shellfish.
It has been thirty-five years since his mother-in-law died and he started working in the business that she left behind in order to continue the family business. He effectively runs his business, so many tourist know where to go to rent umbrellas. He works from 6am until 5pm on the beach renting umbrellas for $5.00 including a chair. Tents rent for about $5.00, depending on their size. 
In order to continue with his business, he would like to buy, with this loan, umbrellas, tents, and chairs for his customers so that he will have a variety of products. In the future he would like to have a booth on the beach in order to provide better service to his customers.

loans.use: Umbrellas, tents and chairs

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is a 58-year-old married man with eight children.  He is able to raise his family with the income he gets from farming.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become financially stable.  He desires to become a well-known farmer in the future.  He has requested 40,000 Kes to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Marceline

texts.en:
Marceline F., from the village of Talahiron, Kibawe, Bukidnon, is 41 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marceline owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and snack foods in the local community. Engaged in her business for over eight years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marceline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 4000 PHP to purchase additional products including beverages and biscuits, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as beverages & biscuits

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Sabougnouman sont mariées majoritairement  dans des ménages polygames ayant en moyenne 43 ans, 5 enfants et habitant ensemble dans le village de Cinzana Gare chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de draps de lit, de couvre lits et de condiments alimentaires (Sounbala, poudre de gombo, de piments, etc). 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 4ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Sitan S. est beaucoup sollicité à Cinzana Gare pour la vente des draps pendant les 12 mois de l’année. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter trente draps en gros au grand marché de Ségou. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, au marché de Cinzana Gare et dans les villages environnants à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Sitan S. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les besoins de condiments du foyer. 
Elle a pour objectif de s’investir dans l’élevage des petits ruminants dans le futur.
texts.en:
The seven women of  the Sabougnouman group are mostly married in polygamous families. They have an average age of 43 and five children, and live together in the village of Cinzana Gare, capital of a rural province in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know one another through ties of neighborhood, marriage and family.
Group members are trading bed sheets, bed coverings and spices (Sounbala powder, curry, pepper, etc.).
In order to improve their business, the members of this group have joined Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their fourth round of loan.
Ms. Sitan S. faces a large demand of bed sheets in Cinzana Gare during the 12 months of the year.
She intends to use her loan to buy thirty sheets at the general wholesale market in Ségou. Resale is made in cash or credit, at home, at the market of Cinzana and in the surrounding villages, to a clientele made mainly of women. 
With this loan Ms. Sitan S. hopes to achieve an average monthly profit of 40 000Fcfa to be reinvested in the business and to respond to the demand of spices in their neighborhood. In the future she would like to invest in the husbandry of small animals.

loans.use: Purchase of bed bed sheets

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is currently in business selling coffee and sugar.  She is 30 years old, married to a seller of soap, and has 6 children.  Three of them go to school.  Jane has requested a loan to stock more coffee and sugar.  With extra profits, Jane hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more coffee and sugar

loans.name: Mlongo

texts.en: Mlongo is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. For over 10 years, she has operated a mahamri (dumplings) business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mlongo faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to establish a restaurant business in the future. With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase two bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat oil and sacks of sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase two bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat oil and sacks of sugar

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
Zafar B. is 29 years old. He has had a trying life but he keeps an optimistic outlook. He remains a strong and persevering person, intent on improving his family’s standard of living. Zafar sells petrol and diesel fuel. Over three years of selling fuel, he already has got enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him. 

Today Zafar is requesting a loan of 7,500 TJS that will be used for increasing his inventory and meet his clients' demands. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Zafar’s business, and they will sincerely thank you.
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more fuel in order to expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “CHOQUEQUIRAO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Carlos; el tiene 50 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; el socio se dedica a la artesanía a la pintura, el socio compra materiales como pinceles, oleos para así poder realizar su trabajo, él expone sus pinturas en un local ubicado en la plaza de armas de Cusco, él socio a la vez trabaja en el ministerio de cultura ,el socio es una persona bien alegre y con muchas ganas de seguir adelante.

El socio solicita el préstamo para la compra de materiales para seguir realizando su arte.

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos
texts.en:
Sr. Carlos is a member of the Communal Bank “Choquequirao” which is located in the District, Province, and Department of Cusco.

He is 50 years old, in a common law marriage, and has two children. Carlos produces paintings and will purchase materials such as brushes and oil-based paints to complete his work. He exhibits his paintings from a space in the Plaza de Armas in Cusco. At one time, Carlos worked for the Ministry of Culture. He is a cheerful person who has tremendous desire to succeed. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy materials to continue with his art.

Carlos is happy with the loan and promises to complete his payments.

loans.use: To purchase art supplies and materials.

loans.name: Hacia Un Futuro Mejor 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Reymundo is the coordinator of his group, Hacia un Futuro Mejor 1 & 2  (To a better future). He makes his home here in a simple structure with his long-term partner and 3 of their five children. 

Reymundo is excited to be requesting his 4th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid his previous loan and grown his business. He has had his business for 8 months, selling miscellaneous products. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business by buying rice, flour and other foods.  His business is a colmado, a place where you can find all the ingredients to make your daily food.  Normally these colmados are in the neighborhood so that there is only a short walking distance from any home. He will use the profits to proviD. for his home, and to pay for his children's education.  One of his dreams is to see them become professional. 

This Esperanza associate's story is representative of his group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). His group is located in the city of Hato Mayor, one of the country’s most rural cities whose economy depends on agriculture. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: to buy beans, sugar, rice, onion, oil, canned products, etc.

loans.name: Elvis Helio

texts.es: Elvis  tiene 22 años de edad. Es soltero y no tiene hijos. Vive en casa de sus padres en la parte rural del distrito de Tucume en Lambayeque, Perú. Gana la vida criando y vendiendo animales en un pequeño terreno cerca de su domicilio. Cuando sus animales ya han alcanzado un buen tamaño y peso, los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona. Ya cuenta con una clientela establecida. Tiene 2 años de experiencia en este rubro. Desea usar su crédito será para la compra de más animales y alimento balanceado. También, pretende hacer unos arreglos a sus corrales para mejor proteger sus animales del sol. Por ello, ha creído conveniente solicitar un préstamo de 1200 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva Field Partner).
texts.en:
Elvis is 22 years old, single, and has no children. He lives in the home of his parents in the rural section of the District of Tucume in Lambayeque, Peru.  Elvis earns his living by raising and selling animals from a small piece of land near his home.  When the animals have reached a good size and weight, he offers them for sale to traders who frequently visit the area.  Elvis already has an established customer base and has worked in this type of business for two years.  

He wants to acquire more animals and balanced feed.  In addition, he needs to make a few repairs to the animal pens so that he can better protect his livestock from the sun.  For this reason, he is requesting a loan of 1200 PEN from Edpyme Alternativa (a Kiva Field Partner).

loans.use: To repair his animal pens as well as purchase balanced feed and more livestock.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 36-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and two kids. Ibrahim has been a wholesale food supplier since 2006. He is a hard worker with a good reputation for his commitment and proficiency at work. Most of his clients are from Bint Jbeil. 

Ibrahim is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy cigarettes and tobacco. He introduces new products gradually to his customers in order to assure his products are all sold out. Ibrahim would like to buy a big and modern pickup truck in the future to transport the products sold to customers as an additional service.

loans.use: to buy cigarettes and tobacco

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es: Dionicia tiene 50 años, es separada y vive con sus 3 hijos en su casa que es propia. Hace más de 18 años que se dedica a la ganadería y agricultura, actualmente sus hijos la ayudan en esta actividad, dando de alimentar a sus animales y cuidar de su salud. Las ventas de estos animales lo hacen en temporada de ferias que se presentan en su ciudad. Asimismo se dedica a la agricultura donde cultiva papa, maíz y habas que vende después de cada cosecha y esto dura alrededor de 6 meses, por lo que tiene que esperar vendiendo animales para así no dejar de generar ganancias. Considera además que las variaciones climáticas afectan seriamente su cosecha por lo que se concentrará en estos próximos meses en aumentar su capital de trabajo en animales vacuno y ovino. Es su crédito número 14 que tiene con MFP, considera que pertenecer a su banco comunal es una valiosa experiencia que le sirve para mejorar su economía en el aspecto de saber distribuir adecuadamente sus ingresos y esta muy agradecida por esto por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de más animales como cerdos.
texts.en: Dionicia is 50 years old, separated, and she lives with her 3 children in a house which she owns. She has been a cattle farmer and agriculturist for more than 18 years. Her children help her in these activities, feeding the livestock and taking care of their health. She sells her livestock during the season when the fairs come to town. She is also involved in agriculture, cultivating potatoes, corn, and fava beans. She sells the products after every harvest, lasting about 6 months. So while she waits to sell her livestock she is still able to earn an income. She also considers the climate variations that seriously affect the harvest which is why she will concentrate the following months on increasing her working capital, in the form of cattle and sheep. This is her 14th loan with MFP (Kiva Field Partner) and she believes that being part of her communal bank is a valuable experience. It helps her with her finances especially in knowing how to adequately distribute her income. She is very thankful and she is committed to be on time with her payments. With the loan that she requests she will invest in the purchase of more livestock, including pigs.

loans.use: to purchase pigs.

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s crockery selling business. He operates his business on a cart. He sells crockery items like cups, teapots, glasses etc. He is very fair in his rates and makes good profits from his business. With the loan, he will buy crockery items to offer more variety to his customers, which will help him increase his profits and sales. He has had this business for the past nine years and Saima hopes that a loan will bring positive changes to his business and improves his income. 

Saima herself is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is a very active and responsible person and performs her tasks very well. She has given birth to four children: two sons and two daughters. Only her eldest son is enrolled in a school. The others are very young and have not started their education yet. 

Saima is a very responsible loan user of Asasah. She has been receiving loans from Asasah for the past four years. She has always paid her installments on time and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy crockery to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence, 35, is a single mother of three children. She has been operating a grocery store for the past three years. The business earns her a monthly income of 30,000 KES.

This is Florence’s second loan with KADET LTD; she successfully managed to pay off her previous loan. She will use the loan amount to buy ten sacks of tomatoes, five sacks of onions, ten sacks of potatoes and one sack of cabbages for sale.

Florence intends to use the anticipated profits to educate her children and hopes to supply groceries to big hotels in the future.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, onions, cabbages and potatoes for sale

loans.name: Josiha

texts.en:
Josiha is 44 years old. His spouse is Ann, and they have two children, aged 10 and 6 years.  

He runs a butchery in the Kiboswa trading center and has been in the business for a period of 10 years, earning a monthly income of 20,000 Kenyan shillings.

He has borrowed a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings for his first term loan from KADET, and he hopes to use the money to purchase a sheep and goats for slaughter. The profits will be used for the welfare of his family.

He hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and goats for slaughter.

loans.name: Nizam

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 45 years old, married and has six children. Two of the children work.

Nizam has had a food market since 2009, selling soft drinks, juices, cheese and dairy products. She has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. Her market is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by. 

She is requesting a $3,000 loan to buy two refrigerators and a generator and to add more foodstuffs to her market. She is aiming to gain more profits so she can improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy two refrigerators, a generator and more foodstuffs for her market.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua is divorced and has two children. Akua sells banku and salted fish (locally called kako) at Abura, which she has done for five years. Her ex-husband assists her in taking care of the home. Akua will use the loan to purchase more salted fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Akua plans to reinvest back into the business for further growth.

loans.use: to purchase more salted fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise and natural products to sell in her store.

loans.name: Ma. Teresa

texts.en:
Ma. Teresa is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is a widow with four children. 

Ma. Teresa peddles snacks like tapioca chips, banana chips, & takudo (taro rootlet) chips. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) to buy raw ingredients for making chips to sell. 

Ma. Teresa is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Ma. Teresa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks

loans.name: Sonia Del Rocío

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Ave Fénix.
 
En este lugar conocimos a la señora Sonia, tiene 50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cinco hijos, cuatro de ellos mayores de edad y dos de ellos estudian en universidad,  el menor tiene 13 años el cual estudia en colegio, Su esposo es sastre.

Nuestra amiga trabaja junto al esposo en el taller de costura que ellos tienen en el centro de la ciudad, ellos confeccionan ropa de hombre como pantalones, camisas y ternos en cualquier modelo, trabaja todos los días desde las 8h00 hasta las 19h00 que cierran su local pero en muchas ocasiones el trabajo no termina allí ya que en casa ellos siguen realizando sus obras cuando tienen mucho que entregar, nos cuenta nuestra amiga que llevan más de 20 años dedicados a esta actividad y que a pesar de que la ropa industrializada llega mucho ellos tienen suficientes clientes que prefieren confeccionar sus prendas en su loca.

Este crédito es para comprar material de costura como hilos, telas, cierres, botones entre otras cosas. Lleva dos años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias a los créditos ella puede colaborar más con el negocio.
 
Sus sueños son seguir adelante y gozar de buena salud.
texts.en:
The members of the "Ave Fénix" (The Phoenix) communal bank meet every 15 days in the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí province.  Portoviejo has been known for many years as the "City of the Royal Tamarind Trees".

Sonia, is 50, married, and has 5 children; 4 of them are adults, and 2 are at university. The youngest is 13, and in high school.  Her husband is a tailor. Our friend works alongside her husband in the tailoring shop they own in the center of the city. They make men's clothing, such as pants, shirts and suits in any pattern.

They work every day from 8:00am to 7:00pm when they close their shop; but often the work doesn't finish there, since at home they keep working when they have a big order to complete.  Our friend tells us that she has done this work for more than 20 years, and that in spite of all the mass-produced clothing that is available, they have enough customers who prefer to have their clothes made in her shop. 

This loan is to buy materials for sewing such as thread, fabric, zippers, bottons, and other things.  She has been with the communal bank for 2 years and she likes it, because thanks to the loans, she is able to contribute more to the business.  Her dream is to move forward in life and to enjoy good health.

loans.use: To buy fabric, zippers, thread, bottons, etc.

loans.name: Federica

texts.en:
Federica is 48 years old and blessed with three children. She lives with her family in a village and generates her income through vegetable production and sales. She aims to earn more income to provide for her family's needs and to save for the future of her children.

Now she wants to plant more vegetables to increase her production but, due to insufficient capital, she is asking for a loan of P15, 000 (Philippine pesos) to buy seeds and fertilizers. She believes that the loan will help her to increase her yields. She is hoping that she is going to harvest a large volume of vegetables and earn a higher income to support her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers to sustain her vegetable production

loans.name: Aimira's Group

texts.en:
Aimira is the treasurer of this group. She is 36 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she brings up a daughter and a son, both children study at school. Ten years ago the family started to breed cattle and now Aimira sells dairy products to make money for livelihood. She applies for the loan because she needs additional money to purchase one more cow for breeding. In the future Aimira dreams to purchase a car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Gliseth

texts.es: Gliseth, de 26 años es una valerosa madre soltera. Ella cuida de sus 3 hijos: Milagros, Norma y Erick a los que cuida en su casa propia, ubicada en el centro poblado Unión Autiki. Ella es una mujer llena de ambiciones. Su sueño es contar con sus propios terrenos de cultivo y así poder sembrar productos oriundos de la selva. “Con esfuerzo y trabajo lo lograré”, afirma, pues ella solo trabaja como peón en diferentes sembríos. Cuenta que le pagan por jornada 20 soles diarios, con ello compra el alimento y vestido de sus hijos; pero en campaña de cosecha de café, obtiene mayor dinero. La modalidad de trabajo es diferente, pues le pagan de acuerdo a la cantidad de grano que recolecta, es ahí donde ella aprovecha al máximo, trabajando desde las primeras horas del día hasta el anochecer. Porque está ahorrando para contar con sus propios terrenos de cultivo y así brindar a sus hijos la educación que se merecen.  Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Mujeres Unidas” y este es el primer crédito con MFP, donde espera del apoyo de todos ustedes para continuar con sus objetivos. Además promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Gliseth de recibir su apoyo, invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de calaminas para techar su casa.
texts.en:
Gliseth, 26, is a valiant single mother.  She cares for her three children, Milagros, Norma and Erick, in her own house located in the town of Unión Autiki. 

She’s a woman who is full of goals.  Her dream is to have fields of her own to plant crops that are typical of the jungle.  “With effort and work, I will accomplish it,” she affirms for she currently works as a field hand in various fields.  She comments that she’s paid 20 soles per day and she uses them to buy food and clothing for her children.  During the coffee harvest season, however, she earns a larger amount of money.  Work modality here is different because she’s paid according to how much coffee beans she picks and this is where she takes advantage to the maximum working from dawn to dusk because she’s saving up to buy her own fields and to provide her children with the education they deserve.

She’s a member of the “Mujeres Unidas” (United Women) communal bank and this is her first MFP loan where she hopes to have support from all of you.  In addition, she promises to be punctual with her installment payments.  If Gliseth were to receive your support, she’ll invest the requested money in the purchase of plywood to roof her house.

loans.use: to buy plywood to roof her house.

loans.name: Jorge Luis

texts.es: El Sr. Jorge es casado tiene un hijo de 7 años de edad; es un hombre luchador con muchas ganas de salir adelante; él se dedica a prestar el servicio de taxi en su moto taxi por todo el cercado de Ica. También tiene una tienda de abarrotes que es administrada por su esposa; el crédito otorgado lo va a invertir en la compra de mercadería para su tienda ya sea todo tipo de abarrotes (azúcar, aceite, arroz etc.). Su principal desafío del Sr. Jorge es el trabajo que realiza hasta altas horas de la noche por toda la ciudad; su principal sueño es construir su casa ya que ésta no es de material noble. El esta muy agradecido con el crédito otorgado.
texts.en: Jorge’s married and has a 7-year-old son.  He is a tenacious man with a strong drive to get ahead.  He provides taxi services in his mototaxi throughout greater Ica.  He also has a grocery store that his wife runs.  He will use the granted loan to buy merchandise for his store; all kinds of groceries (sugar, oil, rice, etc.)  Jorge’s main challenge is working very late at night throughout the city.  His main dream is to build his house since it’s still not made out of substantial materials.  He is very grateful for the loan he’s been granted.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Julia Lucia

texts.es:
La señora  Julia Lucia se dedica a la venta   tamales  desde hace siete años, a la  venta de tostadas tostadas  desde hace  cinco años y a la venta de servilletas desde hace dos años.
Esta felizmente casada  con el señor  Víctor  Isidro  de  sesenta años de  edad con quien tiene  tres hijos  dos mujeres  María  Viridiana de  veinte tres años de edad y Remedio de  veinte años y  un varón  Víctor de veinte seis años de edad.
La señora  Julia Lucia pidió el préstamo para comprar  maíz para comprar  la elaboración de tostadas  y  hojas de plátano  para la elaboración de   tamales.
Tiene  cincuenta cinco años de edad, uno de sus  sueños es   hacer más grande su  negocio y tener un local para  vender  tamales y comida para obtener más ganancias y ayudar a su esposo en los gastos de la casa.
Si fuera a cambiar de negocio le gustaría vender ropa   para niños y niñas  damas y caballero   en pagos  para  que las personas de su pueblo  ya no vayan a jamiltepec a comprar  lo que hay en su pueblo.
Lo que más le gusta de su negocio es  tortear la masa para  hacer  las tostadas y limpiar las hojas para sus tamales.
Le da las gracias a fundación por darle las herramientas para salir adelante y triunfar.
texts.en:
Julia Lucia has been selling tamales for 7 years, tostadas for 5 years and napkins for 2 years. She is happily married to Victor Isidro, 60, with whom she has 3 children; 2 girls - Maria Viridiana, 23, and Remedio, 20 - and 1 boy, Victor, who is 26. 

Julia Lucia asked for a loan to buy corn to make tostadas and plantain leaves for making tamales. 

She is 55 and one of her dreams is to make her business bigger and have a store where she sells tamales and food in order to make more money and help her husband with their cost of living. If she were to go into a different line of work, she would like to see clothing for kids, women and men on layaway so that the people in her town wouldn't go in to Jamiltepec to buy it anymore. 

What she likes most about her business is shaping the dough for the tostadas and cleaning the leaves for the tamales. She thanks the foundation for giving her the tools to get ahead and to triumph.

loans.use: to buy corn to make tostadas and banana leaves for making tamales.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon is married and blessed with one child. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. He has been running a welding business for the last three years to support his family. He also practices dairy farming to supplement his income. In the next 5 years, he plans to establish a wholesale business. Simon has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy a welding machine. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to adopt the culture of saving.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine.

loans.name: Upendo B Group

texts.en:
Judith is the facilitator of the Upendo B group. Judith and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

She takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Judith had an excellent maize yield harvesting nine bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, she was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Judith and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Judith will educate her children and build a house.

In 2012, the members of Upendo B group will each plant maize between one half and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Rubina Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Rubina Bibi is married with four children. Her eldest son is a mason, the second one is involved in a leather business, and her youngest son is in the 7th grade. She has one daughter who is also studying. 

Rubina and her husband are very hard-working by nature. They both work so that they can help each other financially. Rubina owns and operates a sewing business from her home. She collects orders from community clients and from her relatives. Her fees are based on the work she is asked to do, and her clients don’t argue about the costs because they receive quality and timely work from her. Her husband works for a private organization. He works nine hours per day for a monthly wage.

Rubina is requesting for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. She intends to use the loan to purchase a new sewing machine and unstitched clothes, which she will then sew and sell to her customers. This is the season of marriages, so with a new sewing machine and clothes in bulk quantity, she expects to have good sales and increase her revenue.
  
Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called the Asasah Passbook) is Rubina Bibi.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and unstitched clothes.

loans.name: Blanca Del Carmen

texts.es:
En el Municipio el Sauce departamento de León, la joven Blanca Del Carmen se conoce por ser una persona muy dedicada a su trabajo debido a que ha sabido manejar las condiciones de su vida. Es una joven soltera con espíritu de superar, actualmente trabaja en la alcaldía de dicha localidad.   
 
 Se Presentó a Ceprodel el Sauce, con el fin de solicitar un crédito para mejorar su vivienda familiar, el crédito será invertido  en la compra de zinc y madera, para mejora del techo de su casa.
texts.en: In the Municipality of Sauce, in the Department of Leon, the young Blanca Del Carmen is known for being very dedicated to her job; having learned to manage her life's ups and downs.  She is young and single with an overcoming spirit.  She currently works in the mayor's office of her locality.  She presented herself to the Ceprodel el Sauce Communal Bank with the objective of asking for a credit to improve her family's house.  The credit will be invested in the purchase of zinc and wood to improve their house's roof.

loans.use: purchase zinc and wood.

loans.name: Eddie

texts.en: Eddie has been involved in the farming business for over 15 years and has good experience in it. He is married and has three responsible children. His children help him with the business and earned PHP 15,000 in the last crop. He uses his profits to make repairs to his house and purchases for their daily needs. Until now, he was not be able to put aside finances for his business. So he is requesting a loan of PHP 23,000 to purchase sowing seeds and fertilizers. Hopefully, with the help of his requested loan he could then obtain abundant profit in order to expand his business and improve their lifestyle.

loans.use: to purchase sowing seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Edwin Roman

texts.es: El señor Edwin es un cliente que se encuentra en su segunda secuencia en la institución, el es  soltero  vive en casa de su padre El Sr. Agustín quien se dedica a la llantería, el vive en la zona El tejar de la ciudad de la Paz, el cliente independientemente se dedica a la costura de maletines  pequeños de cuero los cuales tienen mucha demanda porque son de novedad en el mercado, el los vende en la feria mas grande  de la ciudad de El Alto. El joven  Edwin necesita el crédito para la compra de una maquina de coser para la confección de sus mochilas y carteras, es una joven emprendedor con el deseo de tener un taller mas grande y emplear mano de obra, esta agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado ya que gracias al apoyo de la institución salió adelante y creció en su negocio.
texts.en: Edwin is a client with Emprender, and this is his second loan cycle. He is single and lives in the home of his father, Agustín, who works in the tire business. He lives in the neighborhood of El Tejar in the city of La Paz. The borrower works independently, making small bags [briefcases/laptop bags], for which there is great demand because they are new on the market.  He sells his products in one of the largest markets of the City of El Alto.  Young Edwin needs this loan to buy a sewing machine to make his backpacks and wallets.  He is a young entrepreneur with the desire to have a larger workshop and employ workers. He is grateful to the institution for the support provided to him.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 34 years old and married with 4 children. With 3 children in school, Gina works very hard to provide for them.

Gina runs a sari sari store (convenience store) in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her sari-sari store.

Gina has been in this business for 6 years and sells a variety of items such as sardines, sugar, egg, spices, bread, etc.

In the future, Gina would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a resident of Mariakani, Kenya. She is married and runs a green grocery stall which has been operating for the last twenty-three years. Besides this, Martha is a farmer and also sells clothes. 

Martha sold some of her farm produce to obtain capital for the current business. She joined Milango to access credit for further business expansion and is applying for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase additional clothes to sell. 

Her future ambition is to own a parcel of land and construct a house. The challenges she needs to overcome are the high cost of transportation and the related fees she pays the government while operating the businesses.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes to sell.

loans.name: Olataga

texts.en: Olataga is a 33-year-old married woman with three children. She would like to start growing taro, bananas, taamu, etc., to earn a living. Olataga has requested a loan to buy equipment to use for her business. She has been a member of SPBD for 0 years. Olataga will spend her profits to improve her business and improve her family income.

loans.use: to buy a bush cutter, bush knives, shovel, and wheelbarrow for her business.

loans.name: Abrewa

texts.en: Although she has received no prior formal education, Abrewa is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling smoked fish in Kufur (near Cape Coast).
