The only hope to supply a good standard of living is to make use of their farmland to produce more rice and sell it for more income. So S. has made up her mind to take a loan of $1,000 to purchase more farmland. (S.'s husband is presented in the picture with his mechanical plow because S. is not available)

loans.use: To buy more farmland

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora O. is forty-nine years old and married with five children, two boys and three girls, who are all currently in the senior high, junior high and primary schools. Dora lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the western region of Ghana. Wiawso is a farming and commercial town in the region. Dora runs a grocery store, buying her supplies in Kumasi. Her store is in the front of her house, and she also sells vegetables on a tabletop in front of her store. Dora has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to buy provisions in bulk to expand her business. She wants to give her children a quality education and to improve upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Alith

texts.en:
Alith, 36 years old and married with four children, lives with her family in Yarinacocha, a small town next to the city of Pucallpa. Alith and her husband work together and just finished installing a small sawmill next to their home. Their sawmill business is called "La Luz" (The Light).

Alith has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about six years. She used her first loan to invest in a small grocery shop, and although she had her shop, she also decided to support her husband in his timber business. Alith's husband has worked with timber for 10 years. Alith supported him financially with this business, and continues to do so with her loans from Manuela Ramos. Together, Alith and her husband are progressing financially for the good of their family. Alith has requested this loan of 2600 soles to invest in the implementation of her family's new sawmill.

Alith appreciates the financial support she receives from Manuela Ramos. She is committed to continuing to work with Manuela Ramos as she has learned to trust the organization. Alith appears in this picture with two of her four children.

loans.use: Implementing a small sawmill

loans.name: Anjelina

texts.en:
Ajelina is a member of the Bwawani borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 48 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.Her child is aged 13 years.she also cares for other 1 dependent.

Ajelina started her own clothing business selling clothes 8 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzania shillings. 

This is Ajelina`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 350,000 In order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan AJelina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mr. Leng P., 50, pictured with his wife, Mrs. Vy Dong, 54, were married in 1979 and have seven children: three sons and four daughters. Five of them are married and live outside the family home, one son works in plywood factory, and one daughter is a cashier, working for a restaurant in Phnom Penh. The family lives along National Road Number One about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Leng has been a chef for three years. He cooks for wedding ceremonies and other Khmer ceremonies. His wife has been selling soft drinks for five years as well. She operates the business in her village.

Now Leng is applying for his first loan of $1,000 in order to purchase a motorbike for commuting and also to buy more soft drinks for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his business and to buy soft drinks for his wife to sell

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn F. is from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. She is 29 years old. Jovelyn is married and has 4 young children. To make a living, Jovelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling of scrap materials in the local community. Jovelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jovelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en:
C., 52, is a low-income person living in Banteay Meanchey province. She is married to Sameoun, 62, who appears in the picture above, and who owns a motor which he uses for a taxi service. They have four children: One is married and lives separately, two work as motor-taxi drivers, and another one is attending school.

C. is currently a domestic tailor who sews her nearby neighbors’ clothes. Also, she owns a few rooms which she rents out to people for a fee. To better satisfy her customer's requirements, she is looking for capital in order to build more rental rooms.

loans.use: To build more rental rooms

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 50 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions and has been in the business for the past 15 years. She uses part of her profit for the family upkeep and invests the rest in her business.  She hopes for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 45 years old and married with five children aged between 6 and 20. She runs a tailoring business in Nairobi, making children's plastic pants. She has had her business for five years and is requesting a loan of Kes 15,000 to purchase materials in rolls. Beatrice describes herself as hardworking, determined and consistent and hopes to become a major supplier of her products. Her dream is to be able to pay for quality education for her children. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To purchase materials in rolls

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new clothing and shoes for men and women

loans.name: Adjeley Adam

texts.fr: Mme W. Adam est couturière de profession 38 d'age elle a optenu son diplôme de couture à L'ICCP du TOGO. Trés top elle a abondoné ces etudes en classe de CE2 pour apprendre la couture.Une expérience dans la confection des chemises pour hommes. Elle sollicite une premier crédit de 300 000 F CFA sur une durée de 10 mois pour acheter des tissus et autres produits entrant dans la fabrication des chemises.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adam W. is a seamstress by profession. She is 38-years-old. She received her seamstress diploma at L'ICCP in Togo. At the top of her class, she left school in 2nd grade to learn to sew. She is experienced in making men's dress shirts. She is asking for her first loan of 300,000 FCFA over a period of 10 months to buy fabric and other products which go into the making of dress shirts.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Fabric and Other Materials for Men's Dress Shirts

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 53 years old. She is married with 5 children. Her youngest child is 20 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells blocks to make a living. She is requesting for a loan amount of 50,000 Nigeria Naira to purchase more blocks to sell. She is a LAPO client. The Lift above poverty organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more blocks to sell

loans.name: Jacinto Cell A Rukia Candiru Group

texts.en: Rukia C. is the group representative of this group in Jacinto Cell. She is 35 years old and married with seven children, of whom five are going to school. She is operating a charcoal selling business, which she has been doing for over three years. She will be using the loan to purchase and transport charcoal from different villages to the market. She is improving: previously she had been purchasing ten bags of charcoal, but at present she buys twenty or more. She is hard-working and has a positive attitude. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and transport it to market.

loans.name: Devora Odila

texts.es:
Devora Odila V. tiene 43 años de edad y vive con su esposo Pablo y sus cuatro hijos.
La socia es un miembro de la ventanilla rural Yagui Grande en el cantón de San Miguel en la provincia de Bolívar.  Son 38 socios en total, los cuales la mayoría se dedican a la agricultura y la crianza de animales menores.
Devora se dedica a la agricultura desde muy temprana edad y además tiene una pequeña tienda.  Dentro de la agricultura los productos que más siembra son maíz, habas, papas, trigo, y legumbres en pequeñas cantidades.  Solicita el crédito para trabajar en la agricultura y parte para invertir en el pequeño negocio de la tienda.  Ha sacado un préstamo antes también para la agricultura y en la educación de sus hijos.

En la foto sale con su esposo Pablo, quien también es socio de su ventanilla rural. Tambien están sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
Devora Odila V., 43, lives with her husband, Pablo, and their four children. She is a member of the Yagui Grande communal bank in the San Miguel region in the Bolívar province. There are 38 members in all. Most of them work in agriculture and raise small animals. Devora has worked in agriculture from a very young age. She also has a small store. The agricultural products that she plants the most are corn, beans, potatoes, wheat, and a small amount of vegetables. She is asking for the loan for her agricultural work. She will use part of the loan to invest in her small business, the store. She has taken a loan before, which she used for agriculture and for her children’s education. Devora is pictured with her husband Pablo, who is also a member of her village bank. Two of their children are also pictured.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Part for agricultural work and part to invest in her small store

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa B. is a 37-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy 7, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling dried fish and rice. Marissa’s 38-year-old husband, Joven, is a also a dried fish vendor. They have three children who are between 12 and 18 years old. The children are currently going to school and also help their parents with the business as part of their daily chores. Marissa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1993 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family's income with her business. Now she earns an average monthly income of 40,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Marissa is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP was used to fund the operations of her businesses and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 10th loan in the amount of 19,500 PHP which she intends to use on her dried fish and rice business. Marissa is working hard to achieve the dreams and aspirations she has for her family which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth G. V. is a 56-year-old mother who lives with her family in Heredia, located in the central valley of Costa Rica. She manages a restaurant named ¨Soda Escuela Rafael Moya¨ which translates roughly as “The Restaurant of the Rafael Moya School”.

Elizabeth has dedicated the last ten years of her life to working hard, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m., Monday to Friday, and from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Saturdays. She is dedicated to the success of her business. In a good month, Elizabeth expects to earn 2,000,000 colons, in a bad month, only 1,500,000.

As a result of the success the restaurant has enjoyed, Elizabeth has been able to hire three employees. In this way, she has independently created work for herself and others in her community. Elizabeth says that a challenge in running her business has been coping with thieves.

Elizabeth prepares food for school children, but she also sells candies. She plans to use this loan to make general investments in restaurant inventory which will help her to offer high quality products to her clients.

Elizabeth hopes to be able to earn enough money one day to purchase a house for her children. Elizabeth also aspires to be the owner of a restaurant; presently she rents the space the restaurant occupies.

loans.use: To purchase restaurant inventory

loans.name: Wilmer

texts.es:
Wilmer tiene 30 años, es un padre de familia muy amoroso y responsable. Vive de manera independiente en la casa de sus padres, junto a su esposa Damiana de 29 años y su querida hija Milagros de 7 años, a quienes desea brindar una mejor vida.

Desde muy joven aprendió de sus padres a trabajar en la chacra, todos los días ayudaba en el trabajo, ya que era consiente que de ello dependía el bienestar de su familia. Actualmente tiene sus propias tierras, las cuales cultiva con muchas ganas, ya que sabe que ahora de está actividad depende el bienestar de su esposa y su hija.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cuidar sus cultivos y se siente muy feliz cuado los ve grandes y abundantes; lleva 18 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es llevar lo cosechado hasta el mercado de la ciudad de Tarma, que es el lugar donde los vende.
Para más adelante, desea comprar nuevas tierras y así incrementar su producción.

Este es el sétimo préstamo de Wilmer con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente y está dispuesto a hacerlo, ya que no desea meter en problemas a su banco comunal, donde es un socio muy solidario y responsable. Con los tres mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará semillas de papa y alverja, ya que estos productos se están vendiendo muy bien estos meses.
texts.en:
Wilmer is 30 years old and a loving responsible father. He lives independently at the home of his parents with his wife Damiana (age 29) and their beloved daughter Milagros (age 7). They hope to provide her a better life.

From a young age, Wilmer learned from his parents how to work on a farm. Every day he helped them with their work since he was conscious that his family’s welfare depended on it. He currently has his own land that he has cultivated with great success since now the welfare of his wife and daughter depend on his work. What he enjoys most about his job is looking after his crops and feeling extremely happy when his harvests are large and abundant. Wilmer has been farming for 18 years and considers the most difficult part to be hauling his produce to the market in the city of Tarma, the place where he sells them. Later on, he wants to buy additional land so that he can increase his production.

This is his seventh loan with MFP. Wilmer knows he has to submit all of his payments on time and is inclined to do so because he does not want to cause problems for his Communal Bank. He is a very supportive and responsible member. With his loan of 3000 PEN, Wilmer will buy seeds for planting potatoes and peas since these products have been selling well in recent months.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds for planting potatoes & peas

loans.name: Macaria

texts.es:
Macaria pertenece al banco comunal “Reyna D. los Ángeles”, ella es una D. las fundadoras del banco comunal. 

Macaria, tiene 69 años, tiene siete hijos. Ella es una madre responsable que busca a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus menores hijos. 

Macaria se dedica a la venta D. chicha D. jora (La chicha D. jora es una bebida ancestral en el Perú y América, y su principal ingrediente es la jora o maíz fermentado.). Macaria en su domicilio acomodo una habitación y la convirtió en una picantería (Lugar donD. se venD. la chicha D. jora que se caracteriza por tener una bandera D. color rojo amarrado con una flor que se cuelga en la puerta principal del local). Ella solo los días miércoles venD. la chicha D. jora.

Macaria también se dedica a la venta D. verduras por mayor, ella distribuye sus productos a las vendedoras D. la feria D.  mercado D. Huancaro. Ella también envía verduras para vender en la ciudad D. puerto Maldonado. La socia nos cuenta que tiene una chacra en Puerto Maldonado donD. produce castaña, Su esposo le envía castaña para que ella venda en la ciudad del Cusco,  Ya son 20 años que se dedica a la venta D. verduras y le ha ido muy bien. 

Macaria requiere el préstamo para comprar semillas D. verduras y castaña. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Macaria belongs to the Communal Bank “Reyna D. los Ángeles” (Queen of the Angels) and is also one of the founding members. She is 69 years old and has seven children. Macaria is a responsible mother who looks at each moment as an opportunity to succeed. Each day she strives to proviD. a better future for her younger children.

Macaria sells “chicha D. jora” (an ancestral beverage of Peru and the Americas that is maD. from fermented corn). She set asiD. a room in her house and converted it into a “picantería” (a place that sells “chica D. jora” and is identified by a red flag tied to a flower that hangs on the front door of the building). Macaria sells this product only on Wednesdays.

In addition, Macaria sells vegetables in bulk. She distributes her products to the vendors at the market fair in Huancaro. Macaria also ships vegetables to be sold in the city of Puerto Maldonado. She says she has a farm in Puerto Maldonado that produces chestnuts. Her husband ships the chestnuts to be sold in the city of Cusco. She has 20 years of experience selling vegetables and has done very well.

Macaria needs a loan to purchase vegetable seeds and chestnuts. She is grateful for this opportunity and commits to making her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds & chestnuts

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 28 year old married lady with a son who attends school.  She has a timber yard where she sells poles and posts.  She was selling clothes before she ventured into this business.  

Joyce is a member of a group named Hope.  She has benefited from the group because the members meet on weekly basis to share business ideas and also save money.  She plans to increase her stock of poles and posts, and to start selling sand.  Therefore, she has requested a loan of KES 80,000 from Faulu Kenya.  She is determined to open up a hardware shop and dreams of building her family a house in the future.

loans.use: To increase her stock of poles and posts, and buy sand for sale

loans.name: Fátima Del Rosario

texts.es:
La Señora Fátima del Rosario R., tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación en el reparto 12 de septiembre, además de su pulpería que la administra su esposo ella vende ambulante con un carretón de mano verduras por las mañanas en las calles aledañas a su comunidad.
La Señora R. es una señora luchadora que se esfuerza trabajando diario de lunes a domingo de 6 de la mañana a 9 de la noche tuvo 6 hijos pero de estos solo tres estan bajo su cargo en edad escolar, tiene 6 años de tener esta pulpería comenzó su negocio con un capital de 500 córdobas ahorro propio anteriormente ella echaba tortilla. Lleva tres años de trabajar con ceprodel en los cuales los financiamientos les han servido de mucho porque ella a mejorado su negocio y su calidad de vida tambien.
texts.en:
La Señora Fátima del Rosario R., tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación en el reparto 12 de septiembre, además de su pulpería que la administra su esposo ella vende ambulante con un carretón de mano verduras por las mañanas en las calles aledañas a su comunidad. La Señora R. es una señora luchadora que se esfuerza trabajando diario de lunes a domingo de 6 de la mañana a 9 de la noche tuvo 6 hijos pero de estos solo tres estan bajo su cargo en edad escolar, tiene 6 años de tener esta pulpería comenzó su negocio con un capital de 500 córdobas ahorro propio anteriormente ella echaba tortilla. Lleva tres años de trabajar con ceprodel en los cuales los financiamientos les han servido de mucho porque ella a mejorado su negocio y su calidad de vida tambien.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de productos para mi negocio

loans.name: Nhan

texts.en: Mrs. Nhan R. is a 30-year-old resident of Kompong Cham Province. She lives in her own old wooden house with other family members and makes a living as a farmer, growing various crops. Her husband who appears on the right in the photo also assists her on the farm. This couple is blessed with three kids who are attending school and under their care. Nhan R. will be using her loan to hire a laborer to clean up her farmland, as well as buy fertilizer. Then she will plant her potato crop.

loans.use: To hire a laborer and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Kulai's Group

texts.en:
Kulai A., 58, is the leader of the group. Her husband is retired. She has a son and two daughters. Her son works as a welder and the daughters own a private sewing workshop. Sometimes they send pieces of material that are left over after production and Kulai makes traditional clothes and accessories. In this way she makes 1500 soms ($32.65) per month. Kulai and her husband also breed livestock. With money received from the loan, she will purchase 30 chickens and two other farm animals in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future Kulai plans to buy a kiosk and sell convenience goods.

Toktogul M. is 63. His wife is retired. They have a grandchild who studies at school. Toktogul and his wife have been breeding livestock for a long time. When necessary, they sell livestock to make money. In this way they make 2000 soms ($43.54) per month. Toktogul applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase cattle for breeding.

Mairmakan K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 61 and married. They have two sons, who fish to earn money. Six years ago, with the initial investment of 500 soms ($10.88), Mairamkan began to take orders and sew traditional clothes. In this way she earns 1500 soms ($32.65) per month. That profit made her able to purchase cattle for 18000 soms ($391.90). Mairamkan needs a loan to purchase one cow and two other farm animals. In the future she wants to expand the business and export her products to Kazakhstan.

Kanymbubu I. is 60. Her husband is retired. Their grandchild lives with them; he is thirteen and attends school. Kanymbubu and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating different fruits and vegetables for about 40 years. Selling fruits and vegetables they make 2000 soms ($43.54) per month. Kanymbubu applied for the loan, because she needs money to pay for tractor services and purchase fuel, which is needed for the sowing process in the summer season.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase 30 chickens and two other farm animals

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 42-year-old married woman with six children in school. She has been operating a salon for the past five years. She also sells charcoal to earn extra income. Her husband assists her in managing her business together with three other employees.

Elizabeth is a member of Kyumbi Ebenezer group with Faulu Kenya; the members guarantee each other's loans. She has requested a loan of KES 70,000 to buy salon equipment. She hopes to educate her children to university level in the future. She also dreams of owning a plot of land in the future.

loans.use: To purchase salon equipment

loans.name: Noraisa

texts.en:
Noraisa S. is from the city of Barangay 5 tangub City. She is 26 years old. Noraisa is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Noraisa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling clothes, slippers and etc.in the local community. Noraisa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Noraisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noraisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Noraisa is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Noraisa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her retail business

loans.name: Mrs. Im Hon Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nine people who are made a village bank loan located in Char village in Takeo province. All they will use portion of their loan for different purposes in which it can improve businesses. Mrs. Im H. is a village bank president who was born in 1972, selected by the other members. She is a weaver at her home where she can earn some money to support her family while her husband is a tree cutter who owns a timber saw. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Im H. is applying for a loan to buy silk. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a weaver, while other is attending in local public school.

loans.use: To buy silk

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa moved to the United States from Ecuador in 1999 with her family. In Ecuador she received her degree in Business Administration and practiced in the field for 25 years. When she moved to the United States, she didn’t speak English very well, so she wasn’t able to get a job in her field. In 1999, just months after moving to Boston, she started her own day care. 

Starting her own business has allowed Teresa to provide an additional income for her family. She enjoys working with the children and owning her own business. The income generated from her day care also allowed her family to purchase the house in which they are living. 

Teresa’s greatest challenge is the summer months. Between June and August many families take their children out of the day care for vacation and summer camps. During these months, Teresa has a hard time maintaining her cash flow and paying her three employees. Another challenge has been that many parents took their children out of day care during the economic crisis. Many decided to take care of their children at home instead of paying for her services.

This is Teresa’s 2nd loan with ACCION USA, with which she’ll be better able to maintain her business and pay employees during the summer months. She hopes to be better prepared for low attendance next summer, so that she doesn’t run into this problem again. She knows that come September she will be back up to capacity in her day care. Teresa’s day care is well known in the greater Boston area and she receives many new clients through referrals.


About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA
Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education.

Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild the economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To maintain cash flows & employees during slower summer months
